The bloke that refused to count the hands there, I might say, was a union boss from Victoria. What is he doing in Townsville?

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Madam President. I just wondered if this diatribe, in your view, was in accordance with the standing orders and relevant to the question that Senator Parer asked.
—I think the topic the minister is discussing is relevant to the question. Fewer interjections would be helpful and the minister ignoring them would also be helpful.

—This enterprise in Townsville would create 1,600 direct and indirect jobs. It would put $84 million annually into the economy. But since this strike has been going, $1 million in wages and another $1 million in flow-on costs have been lost to workers and to that economy. And what do the Labor Party say about it? Absolutely nothing. Where is the support from the opposition benches to get that activity in rural and regional Australia going? It is a marvellous enterprise that would create real activity.
—Where's Cheryl Kernot?
—She was heard to say that she is always in her electorate. She has only been out into rural Australia once since she has been the shadow minister.
—Senator Macdonald, stick to the question and ignore interjections.

—Thank you, Madam President. As I say, this is a stupid inter-union dispute. It follows what has happened in New South Wales. Are there any of you there from New South Wales? What happened in New South Wales when we wanted to give some young people a job? We wanted to develop regional Australia, and in New South Wales the AWU stopped that Work for the Dole program. And what did the New South Wales government and what did you lot from New South Wales do about it? Absolutely nothing. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that local government is deeply concerned about the impact of the GST and that not one local government organisation or council has made a submission to the Senate inquiry supporting the tax package as it currently stands? Has the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government drawn these concerns to the minister's attention, and how does the minister propose to satisfy these concerns?

—I have had the benefit of listening to the questions which have been put to Senator Ian Macdonald in recent times over the effect of the GST on local councils. I do not think I even need to go back to check my Hansard to note that Senator Macdonald is saying that the GST tax reform package is overall going to be of great benefit to local governments.
—That is not what they are saying.

—I was asked whether Senator Ian Macdonald had brought to my attention some of the concerns which Senator Mackay apparently has. What I am saying is that I have listened very carefully to the questioning of Senator Ian Macdonald in the Senate, and Senator Macdonald has made very clear the very substantial benefits local government will receive from the tax reform package. So that answers your question, Senator. You asked me whether Senator Ian Macdonald brought concerns to my attention, Senator, and I said that I have heard him speak on this quite a number of times. Senator Macdonald has been very effective, in my view, in pointing out the very substantial benefits.
—You've made him look good, Rod.

—He is good. You are quite right, Senator Ray. Senator Macdonald is very good. That is one of the reasons that this government is having a lot of rapport with local governments. Thank you, Senator Ray. It is because we have someone of the quality of Senator Macdonald to get out and sell the message.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections on my left and there is too much shouting.

—Local government, along with the rest of the Australia economy, will certainly benefit from the government's tax reform package. Senator Mackay does not like the package but, as I have pointed out, this package is good for local government, good for Australians, good for taxpayers and good for pensioners. The only people, it seems to me, who constantly whinge and moan about it—and failed to convince the Australian people at the election—were Senator Mackay and her colleagues.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that not one submission that has been made to the Senate inquiry from local government supports the tax package as it currently stands. Further, is the minister aware that local government organisations have rejected the government's assertions that local government will be $70 million better off as a result of the GST? Is the minister aware that the Australian Local Government Association, for example, says that it `disputes the magnitude of the direct and indirect financial benefit from the removal of the burden of taxes in the goods and services used by Local Government' and that `despite Local Government request, Treasury will not explain the assumptions underlying its methodology'? Can the minister explain what methodology was used to calculate the $70 million?

—There is a full range of follow-up questions there from Senator Mackay. First of all, you quoted the Australian Local Government Association. I have here a quote from Mr Rod Nettle, and I thank the local government minister for bringing it to my attention. This is what Mr Nettle said—as distinct from the selective quoting that you have been going on with:

answer.para: Senate committees themselves, really are a bit of window-dressing for the government's policy. They are determined to get the GST through, and I think that's fair enough. They can claim a reasonable mandate for it.
This is not me saying this, and it is not Senator Ian Macdonald saying this. This is a quote from Mr Rod Nettle, the CEO of the Australian Local Government Association. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. I refer to the return to order for Jabiluka documents, which the minister partially met on 8 March. I refer in particular to the documents he withheld. Does the minister recall that he listed four grounds for refusal in his tabling statement of 8 March? Does the minister also recall that, in a letter to me 48 hours later, two of his original grounds for refusal had disappeared completely and a new, fifth ground for refusal had been introduced? I notice that the minister has not taken the opportunity to make a correcting statement and an explanation of this to the Senate, and I ask which is the correct statement and the correct list of grounds for refusal—the minister's tabling statement to the Senate on 8 March, or the minister's letter to me on 10 March?
—That is an obscure question. I suggest that the honourable senator takes into account the two reasons that were omitted in the second letter and adds the fifth.

—Madam President, I am not sure that I understand the answer to the question very accurately, but I believe that my question to him was which of those statements is correct. I do not believe that they can both be correct at the same time. However, the minister may enlighten me. On a supplementary question on the same matter, one of the grounds of refusal that I note remained in both of the minister's statements was that the documents were `internal workings of government' and `should not be disclosed on the basis of public interest immunity'. Is the minister aware that this ground was summarily dismissed as a ground for refusal to release documents by Mr Justice Hill of the Federal Court in 1997? Does the minister know that Mr Justice Hill found the government's motivation was `that the public not see what goes on behind closed doors' and that he said that it was `not in the interests of the administration of justice—(Time expired)

—The trouble was, I have to confess, that I did not understand the question; but I will refer to the previous correspondence and write to the honourable senator again and hope that I can clarify those matters. In relation to the Justice Hill judgment, from memory I think that that might have been in relation to the Freedom of Information Act, and I would answer that the rules that we have applied by practice in here over a long period of time do take that act into account and have been in more recent times guided by that act but it is not the total explanation. I will also examine that judgment and see if there is anything I can add to help.

—My question is to Senator Kemp representing the Treasurer. Minister, what is the government's response to Premier Bacon's call for special compensation for Tasmania to offset the negative impact of the GST?

—I make the point that the GST package is one which also benefits states, and that the state governments have signed the agreement because of the benefits that will flow to state governments—who, of course, obtain all the revenue from the GST.
—Will they get more or less?

—We will give them a guaranteed three years and, after that, the robust nature of the revenue flows from GST will be of huge benefit to state governments. I point out that Tasmania, along with other state governments, will certainly benefit from that. We do not accept that any state will be worse off as a result of the GST. All the states will benefit; indeed, the formula that has been established will certainly show that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Assistant Treasurer whether he is aware that the Prime Minister's preferred modeller, Mr Chris Murphy, has calculated that Tasmania will be a net loser of 1,000 jobs under the GST? Doesn't this actually lend weight to the Tasmanian government's claim that the GST will only exacerbate an already poor labour market situation for Tasmania? I ask: what concrete steps is the government going to take to address these Tasmanian concerns?

—The Commonwealth has guaranteed—as I pointed out—that in the three years following the introduction of the GST the budgetary position of Tasmania will be no worse off than it would have been in the absence of tax reform.

—Madam President, on a point of order: I asked the minister—as you would be aware, Madam President—specifically about Mr Chris Murphy's calculation that Tasmania would lose a net 1,000 jobs under the GST. I ask you to ask the minister to address himself—for a change today—to the question before the chair.
—I am sure the minister is aware of the question.

—I was asked in what ways would the economy benefit in Tasmania. Senator, there are quite a range of ways it will benefit. The cost of transporting goods and passengers across Bass Strait will be reduced by the effective limitation of the tax on marine fuel—one big and important benefit to Tasmania. The net excise on diesel fuel used in heavy transport and rail will also fall sharply. That will also be of help in Tasmania. Those who operate in the tourist area will benefit from lower transport costs. So we believe that the overall effect of the GST is good for jobs, good for the economy and good for the states.

—My question is also to the Assistant Treasurer. I ask: will the government legislate to close loopholes in the laws allowing MPs with previous service in state parliaments who have become federal MPs to double-dip by taking a state lump sum as well as a federal pension upon retirement, and, secondly, allowing federal MPs access to superannuation entitlements before the age of 55? I would be quite happy to redirect that question if that is appropriate.
—Senator Kemp has a new look today. That question should rightly have been directed to the Minister for Finance. I think that is what Senator Brown was alluding to at the tail end.
—On a point of order, Madam President: I ask, given that you called Senator Kemp, is it appropriate that Senator Ellison address the Senate in this way, without the call from you?
—I have called Senator Kemp. If he does not wish to deal with the question, I think he should indicate why somebody else has been given the question before it is answered.

—Madam President, I think if the Hansard is reviewed we will see that Senator Brown noted that the question was probably being directed to the wrong minister. I think he said at the end of his question he would redirect his question to the right minister. Is that correct, Senator Brown?
—Yes, that's right.

—In relation to the question by Senator Brown, I can advise the Senate that the arrangements for members with service in more than one parliament are identical to arrangements in the private sector where employees are able to retain the superannuation benefits accrued in that previous employment. In other words, a federal parliamentarian who once served in a state parliament is treated no differently from a federal parliamentarian who once worked for a bank, a law firm or even a trade union. Members elected since 1 July 1994 who have prior state parliamentary service can receive benefits from each jurisdiction that reflect the period of service in each respective parliament. Before that time, the Commonwealth often had to fund both Commonwealth and state entitlements while the state scheme paid nothing. In relation to other matters relating to more personal details, for privacy reasons it would not be appropriate for me to go into them.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: can he not see the concern and the increasing criticism that is coming upon the federal superannuation scheme through the ability of some MPs to be able to double-dip—to wit, to take a lump sum payment from a state parliament superannuation fund of between half a million and a million dollars and then a federal pension on top of that? Does the minister not see that this is inherently wrong, that it is an affront to public sensitivity about the way in which taxpayers' money is spent and that the law needs to change? My second question to the minister was this: will the government review the law to amend it so that superannuation arrangements are not available before the age of 55?

—In relation to Senator Brown's supplementary question, I remind the Senate that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation reported on its inquiry into superannuation for parliamentarians on 1 September 1997. The government responded to that by saying that it would respond to the report in light of changes included in the proposed legislation in the Public Service Bill which has been twice rejected in this chamber. What the government is saying is, firstly, sort out the remuneration package for members of parliament, and then go on to the question of superannuation. But that question of remuneration is tied up in the Public Service Bill, which has been rejected in the Senate. The government still has to deal with that question before it gets on to responding to the committee's inquiry into parliamentary superannuation.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Drug Treatment

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware of recent announcements by the Prime Minister regarding funding for drug treatment activities? Is it not a fact that drug treatment is not included in the definition of a GST exempt health service, unless it is counselling delivered by a registered medical practitioner? Would not the GST apply to accommodation, food and other services provided by community organisations? Will the government increase the grants to community organisations to compensate for the higher costs of delivering services if the GST were to be introduced or will the government be forcing these small community based organisations to pay this new tax out of their existing grants, therefore reducing the real value of the funding?

—I am glad that Senator Evans pointed out the very important announcements that have been made by the Prime Minister in relation to funding for drugs, which we all appreciate is an exceedingly serious problem in the community. Senator, you mentioned treatments provided through registered medically approved arrangements. There are GST arrangements which apply there. A lot of the treatments are, of course, provided through charities. This, I suspect, would typically be of a non-commercial nature and the focal point of much of the work of the charities, and therefore would be GST free.
—No, Senator, you've got that wrong too.

—Non-commercial work of charities is, let me assure you, GST free. I think that much of the work that is being performed is. We are very conscious of the importance of this work. The government is very conscious of the importance of putting in place programs to deal with this problem. As I said, much of the work which was referred to in the latter part of the question is provided by bodies that come under the heading of `charities', and of course that work in the non-commercial area is GST free.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I start by pointing out to the minister that his answer was not related to the question, which was about community based organisations, not charities. So I would appreciate it if the minister would take that question on notice and give us an answer. My supplementary question is: is the minister aware that pharmacists charge people on the methadone program up to $35 a week for dispensing methadone from chemists? Will these charges be exempt from the GST in the same way that the PBS charges are exempt?

—I notice that the senator mentioned that under the current arrangements a charge is made. I would imagine that these are the sorts of products which can only be supplied by chemists, and therefore there are special rules which apply to that under the bill that we have brought before the parliament.

—My question is for the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Ellison. The minister would no doubt be aware of articles in the weekend newspapers regarding the content of some university student handbooks. My question is: who funds these handbooks, and is there any federal funding provided for the publication of these handbooks? Further, will the government's voluntary student unionism bill have an impact on such publications?

—At the outset, I thank Senator Synon for this very important question, and acknowledge her longstanding interest in this very important question. I also want to acknowledge the guffaws from the opposition on what is a very important matter—the question of drug abuse. What we have here is a matter which is a concern for all Australians. At the weekend there were reports of the University of Technology, Sydney, publishing in its orientation day handbook a step-by-step guide to how to inject heroin. This appealed to a young audience—and some 5,000 booklets were issued—an audience which is most at risk in relation to drug abuse. In the article, advice was given on injecting heroin, including how to insert the needle, how to release the tourniquet and how to test if the needle was in the vein. This article has been roundly criticised by the Salvation Army, an organisation which is at the coalface of drug abuse in looking after those with a drug addiction. This publication came from student funds. It came from fees which were compulsorily acquired. It is extremely unhelpful in the face of the government's initiative of Tough on Drugs, where it is spending some $290 million in the war on drugs. This is not about harm minimisation, but about harm promotion.

answer.para: But this is not the first time that student associations have used student funds to produce magazines and handbooks which have included irresponsible articles. Let us remember the ANU student magazine, Woroni, which published an article which gave a number of suggestions for avoiding drink-driving charges. But what about La Trobe University's magazine, Rabelais, which issued a guide on shoplifting? These handbooks are an example of how these compulsory fees are being used in an irresponsible manner. The government believes that student associations do have an important role to play on campuses. I note that Senator Evans had something to say on this. He acknowledged the drug problem in the previous question in relation to counselling. Perhaps he can say whether he thinks that student associations should be publishing articles on how to inject heroin and providing a step-by-step guide.

This government believes in, and is strongly committed to, the principles of the freedom of the individual and particularly freedom of association, as evidenced by our workplace changes and reforms. This government has now honoured its longstanding policy to introduce voluntary student unionism, thereby guaranteeing freedom of association on all Australian university campuses. This is a freedom which my state has enjoyed since 1995. The introduction of VSU will give students the right to choose whether they belong to a student association or not. It will give students greater choice as to what goods and services they wish to use and purchase. They will have a say as to whether they join an association that uses its funds to provide instructions on heroin use. The current compulsory fee applied on most university campuses is charged to students to pay for the services their student association provides as a condition of enrolment and irrespective of whether the students use these services or not. No fee, no degree—that is what these students are faced with on Australian campuses today. In fact, when you look at the compulsory fees involved, you are looking at some $180 to $350 a year, no mean amount for a student. This is a significant compulsory financial burden on students. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister further elaborate on the government's plans for the introduction of voluntary student unionism?

—As I have mentioned, the government does have legislation to provide for this freedom of choice. The government is not saying that people should not belong to a student association, but that they should have the right to choose: they have the freedom to belong to that association or not. As proven in my state already, student services have not diminished. They will not be diminished by the introduction of this legislation. In fact, it will make student associations more competitive in the services they provide to students. They will be forced to look at what students need, not necessarily whether they are going to print articles on how to avoid drink-driving, how to use heroin or how to go about shoplifting. They will have to address the important issues that students are really concerned with. Students do not want their associations printing stuff like we have seen on the weekend, encouraging young people on how to use heroin—and, in the past, showing them how to break the law.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Has the minister changed his mind about scrapping the accelerated depreciation tax concession, in view of the strong criticism of the proposal from the National Party and the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources? Is the minister aware that Senator Minchin has signalled his intention to argue against the plan, and that the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association has stated that it is essential that Senator Minchin be successful? Will the minister persist in the face of such powerful opposition?

—A similar question was asked in this chamber recently. It is probably important to get the facts of this on the table. The Ralph committee has produced a report with various options. Included in those options is the option of looking at the possibility of moving to a 30 per cent company tax rate and looking at the various concessions which are available to business, including the one which was mentioned by the senator—accelerated depreciation. There is an options paper which is now the subject of public debate. Undoubtedly, because this is a very important issue, a range of people are putting forward their views. You mentioned the National Party. That is quite possible. The president of the National Party may well have put forward a view on this. Others are putting forward alternative views. But, Senator, understand there is an options paper in which the Ralph committee—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber and there are too many senators interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam President. A consultation period is currently occurring. People who have views they wish to put to the Ralph committee should put them by 16 April. Senator, you may have a view that you wish to put on the issue of accelerated depreciation.
—What's your view?
—My position will be quite clear. Mine will be the government position.
—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Is the proposed 30 per cent corporate tax rate absolutely dependent on the scrapping of the accelerated depreciation tax concession?

—What you will have to wait for, Senator, is the final report and recommendations of the Ralph committee. There are a whole host of issues which are being considered by the Ralph committee. The issue of accelerated depreciation happens to be one of them. I would urge you to contain your enthusiasm and wait until people have had a chance to put their views to the Ralph committee and the recommendations that the Ralph committee will be making to the government on this important topic. Essentially, we are a low tax party. We are a low tax government. We are different from the Labor Party which, as Senator Cook said, is a high tax party. You can be absolutely assured, Senator, that, whatever we do, we will be heading right in the direction of lower taxes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I refer to the return to order of 16 weeks of Jabiluka documents that the minister partially complied with on Monday, 8 March, and particularly to the documents he withheld. Minister, in your letter to Senator Allison of 10 March, you list a letter written by you to the chair of the World Heritage Committee that you refused to release without the permission of the addressee. However, in partially complying with the return to order, you released no fewer than 11 documents addressed to the World Heritage Committee including at least four personal letters from you to the chair. Did the minister seek and receive the permission of the addressees to release all of these letters? If not, why have you made an entirely arbitrary decision to withhold your letter to the chair of the World Heritage Committee dated 29 January?

—I am surprised to get questions on Jabiluka today because I thought the Democrats would raise the announcement on Beverley and the fact that, since the Senate last met, the government has found all environmental approvals in order and there is $30 million of capital investment with another 400 jobs to be created in South Australia.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. The minister may have wished I had asked a question on Beverley but unfortunately for him I did not. I asked a question on Jabiluka and his return to order. Madam President, I ask you to direct him to the question.

—I take that as a Democrat endorsement of the Beverley uranium mine. They do appreciate the fact that 400 new jobs are going to be created in South Australia, with a $30 million capital investment. It is good for South Australia, good for Australia and good for greenhouse as well. Perhaps that is why the Democrats so approve of it.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. I know that Senator Hill wants to answer questions on Beverley. We would welcome the opportunity to ask two additional questions today. We do not have the chance, unfortunately, to discuss yet another environmentally unfriendly mine. Can he please answer the question directed by Senator Bartlett?
—I draw your attention, Senator Hill, to the question which Senator Bartlett has asked.
—Order! Senators on my left will stop shouting.

—Madam President, I think the honourable senator fails to appreciate that I actually want to give him this letter. As soon as the delivery of the letter has been agreed by the chairman, to whom I wrote, I will give it to him.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In the minister's tabling statement for the documents and in his subsequent letter to Senator Allison he also states that a ground for refusal is that the release of such documents could reasonably be expected to cause damage to the international relations of the Commonwealth. Yet in media releases, in answers in Senate estimates and indeed in answer to a question from Senator Allison in this place on 8 March, the minister stated that he just wanted to get `the true facts about the issue to the members of the World Heritage Committee'. My question to the minister is: if the documents the minister has withheld simply provide the truth and the facts to the World Heritage Committee, how could these true facts reasonably be expected to cause damage to the international relations of the Commonwealth?

—Madam President, it is a long-established principle that governments should have certain confidentiality in their dealings with other governments. It is for a very good reason; that is, if that principle did not exist, other governments would not be so forthcoming and that would be to Australia's detriment. I would have thought that every honourable senator in this place knew that principle and would respect it. That is the way in which we operate and that is the reason why we decline to provide these documents.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Youth Allowance

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Is the minister aware that a senior member of the government's GST task force, which was responsible for designing the GST compensation package, has revealed in testimony to the Senate GST inquiry that at no time was he made aware of the government's commitment to compensate families with a dependent 17- to 21-year-old for the effects of the Youth Allowance? Can the minister explain why the Prime Minister, the Minister for Family and Community Services and the Treasurer, all of whom were aware of this commitment, failed to take any action to ensure it was honoured?

—I would believe that statements which have been made by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer on this matter are absolutely valid. I cannot add anything more to the information which you have sought. I am not aware that a member of the GST task force has made such a comment.
—Why aren't you aware? Don't you read the paper?
—I am not aware. You asked me whether the Prime Minister's comments were correct. As far as I am aware, the Prime Minister's comments were absolutely correct.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It seems that the government cannot be trusted to honour a commitment to compensate families hurt by the changes in the Youth Allowance. How can it be trusted to compensate all families for the GST?

—This is a dreadfully weak question. It goes to my old theory. I am so tired of saying this and advising the Labor Party, `Do not take questions written by Senator Cook.' I have said that on many occasions. What this government wants to do is to keep the promises that we made to the Australian people and on which we were elected. What this Senate should do is insist that the government keep its promises. We believe what we are seeing with Senator Hogg and others is an attempt to frustrate the government, to prevent the government from keeping the promises that we made to the Australian people and on which we were elected.

—My question without notice is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. The government is taking important steps to protect Australian children against highly offensive materials on the Internet. Will the minister inform the Senate of these measures? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —This is a very important social policy issue and I am delighted that Senator Gibson has brought it to the attention of the Senate.
—Can't you be serious about censorship?

—You mightn't be serious about it, but we are. The fact is that the community expects us to take action to ensure that illegal and unacceptably offensive material is not readily available on the Internet just as we take—

answer.para: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know you are the ultimate civil libertarian and you do not care about these things, but there are many hundreds of thousands of Australians who do. We do not allow these things on free to air television. We have very tight restrictions in relation to other mediums and there is absolutely no reason, other than a council of despair, why we should not take a similar approach to the Internet. But what sort of response do we get from the Labor Party? Madam President, I simply do not understand where the Labor Party is on this issue. Even the Democrats gave muted support to the principle, and the Internet Association has just released its own code of practice. On the other side of the chamber, they want to pretend it is—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections. Some senators have been interjecting persistently during question time today. I would ask you to abide by the standing orders.
—Thank you, Madam President. At the moment, you can get snuff movies, paedophile lists, bong recipes, you name it.
—Tell us how you are going to do it.

—Does anyone seriously suggest that we should not be making every effort, that we should not spell out the principles? No, but this is the sort of mindless nonsense you get from poor old Senator Lundy, the shadow for shadows. What we are interested in is doing our best, which is what the Sydney Morning Herald had to say and what anyone who has addressed the issue has to say. What does the shadow minister have to say? You know Glim and Glimmer because you would have seen them on television recently at the leader's CEDA launch. I know you were not there. There were only eight of your colleagues there altogether, but that is more than there were of the business community. That gives you a fair indication of how seriously you are being taken out there. What our Western Australian member of that duo did was, in the morning, to say that the opposition supported measures aimed at restricting Internet pornography. By the afternoon, what he had managed to do was to come out and say that he certainly favoured action being taken to protect children, but as far as he was concerned the most effective way of doing that was to make sure that parents, families and schools were empowered.

answer.para: Of course, `empower' is a very important word in the Labor Party. It is something that they throw around at branch meetings, and it comes up all the time. You can just imagine someone coming home after a hard day's work in the factory, throwing himself down in front of the television and saying, `Please empower me.' Parents want more than that. They do not want you to educate them as to how they can teach their children to handle the Internet—80 per cent of households do not even have the Internet. What conceivable purpose could be achieved by somehow empowering parents? The reality is that you have to take action. You have to be prepared to stand up and lead.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many people on my left shouting throughout the answer to this question.

—I am appalled that CEDA have abandoned their requirement for a quorum. If they had had the usual rules, we would not have all been subjected to the circus of last week. What an embarrassment. I do not know if anyone read Alan Ramsey, but you have got to say it is good value. He said:

answer.para: Any speech that asks 17 questions of itself and then provides no answers beyond generalities and the assertion that the road ahead is all too clearly before us—I am for courage in the face of change.

Here you are: here is an opportunity to be courageous. Get out there and say that you favour principles and that you favour codes of practice that will control access to the Internet. Your shadow minister does not mention X-rated, so what do we take from that? Do we take it that he is relaxed about X-rated, that he has never heard of it or that he doesn't know what to do about it? We are prepared to do something about it. We are standing up on the issue and I hope that you will take the opportunity to address it civilly. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to questions without notice asked today, relating to the proposed new tax system.

In moving this motion, I wish to concentrate on Senator Kemp's first two answers to questions from Senator Cook and Senator Conroy. This is the great sleight of hand, the great con trick proposed by this government that will leave pensioners and those on benefits worse off as a result of the GST. The compensation is inadequate, and it has become clear in recent weeks that, over time, even that meagre compensation will be totally eroded. Pensioners will not be adequately compensated and it is believed that after three or four years there will in fact be no compensation for those on Commonwealth benefits.

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many conversations taking place on both sides of the chamber. If you want to hold a conversation, please do so outside or resume your seats—and do so silently. Thank you very much.

—The government try to hide behind the claim that they are offering an extra 1½ per cent compensation up-front. Of course that is only the case if you accept their modelling, and most people do not because, even on their assumptions, it is quite clear that the price increases will be much greater than they are predicting.

speech.para: Putting that argument to one side for today's purposes, what is clear is that the compensation package will be eroded over time. The churches and charities have been saying this for months, and the Liberal Party have been ridiculing them for making those submissions. But it has now become clear that even the Liberal Party's own economists are saying the very same thing. The other day, we had Geoff Carmody of Access Economics—representing the Australian Food and Grocery Council, part of the Business Coalition for Tax Reform—arguing the same case the churches, the charities and the community groups have been arguing, that is, the compensation for the GST to pensioners will not last and will be eroded. He claims it will be eroded to zero. He says, `Everyone who says the compensation package will not last is dead right.' This bloke ought to have some credibility with this government, because he helped write Fightback—the very agenda which they are seeking to continue to implement.

This is not one of the church groups, one of the charity groups or one of the caring people in the community the Liberal Party are so fond of ridiculing. This is one of their own right-wing economists, representing business interests, who is saying the compensation package will not last, that it will be eroded. He is saying that pensioners in this country will be poorer for a GST. Even on the government's own figures, he is saying, they will be poorer for a GST.

This does not go to the arguments about consumption patterns, which I would like to explore on another occasion. The consumption patterns of pensioners have not been taken into account in designing the compensation; it is an average across all Australian consumers, and pensioners are much higher consumers of food and services that are currently tax exempt, so they will be much more adversely impacted by the GST than the government's figures allow.
Senator Ian Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —But, putting that argument to one side, it is clear that the compensation package is totally inadequate. I think that is why Senator Campbell is so sensitive about it, because it is a fraud, it is a con trick. Geoff Carmody from Access Economics has joined all the charitable groups in saying so. If the government were dinkum, they would fix the compensation as a percentage of male total average weekly earnings, because the government made great play of the need to fix that at a 25 per cent benchmark previously. They said legislation was necessary and they claimed that this was a great achievement of the government. But they will not adjust that compensation to include the GST compensation, because they intend it to be eroded over time. They do not want to preserve it. If they were dinkum, if they were serious, they would increase that percentage to 26.5 per cent or the appropriate figure as a percentage of male total average weekly earnings. I suspect it needs to be higher, but even Mr Carmody is saying it needs to be 26.5 per cent.

speech.para: They are not dinkum. If the government were dinkum about preserving compensation, protecting the poor and protecting pensioners, they would include that definition, increase the compensation and benchmark it. They are not prepared to because they are not dinkum. They know the poor will get poorer, and it is a policy of this government. They do this knowingly. This is not an unforeseen circumstance. The government know that the compensation will be eroded and, as in New Zealand and in Canada, those people on pensions and fixed incomes will be worse off because the compensation will be eroded. It is not adequate anyway, but what little there is will be eroded. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —All Australia knows that the current tax system is an absolute mess. All Australia knows that, everybody knows the tax system is in a mess. But who are against tax reform? The Labor Party. The Labor Party are against tax reform. They have been fighting against everything the government has proposed about reforming taxes. We have put up a comprehensive tax proposal to the Australian community and to the parliament—the ANTS package—which is about reforming indirect taxes and making them fairer and more comprehensive to make sure that those people on social security are guaranteed incomes in the future. That is what the indirect tax reform is about.

speech.para: We are also on about reforming income taxes. The complaints are legion in the income tax field. People on low and medium incomes complain that the marginal rates of income tax are a disincentive to their working, working overtime, working at weekends and working at night. Why? Because the income tax rates they pay are too high. Someone on average weekly earnings in Australia—$38,000 currently—faces a marginal income tax rate of 43 per cent plus 1.5 per cent. Almost half of every extra dollar they earn is lost in taxes to the government. That is why the income tax system has to be reformed. Under our reform proposal, 80 per cent of all income earners—those on incomes of between $20,000 and $50,000—will face a marginal income tax rate of 30 cents in the dollar plus 1.5 per cent, which is a rate of 31.5 cents in the dollar. So they will have incentive to work and to save.

On top of that, we are promising reforms of excise tax. Fuel costs will go down by $3½ billion—$13 billion in income tax and $3½ billion on fuel excise. Fuel cost reductions will have a tremendous impact on transport costs in Australia. Transport costs will go down. Treasury's estimate is that road transport costs in Australia will go down by 6.7 per cent. The Australian Road Transport Forum appeared before the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System a few weeks ago in Sydney and made the prediction that, with the wholesale sales tax reductions and the fuel excise reductions, transport costs for big trucks in Australia will go down by between 15 per cent and 19 per cent.
Senator Sherry interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Of course they will. They gave evidence that when fuel prices go up and down, their costs go up and down. It is a very competitive industry, so that is what is going to happen. These reforms are going to revolutionise Australia and the Australian economy. It is the next big thing that needs to be done in the Australian economy. The Australian economy is going well now. The government has really reformed it. It has stopped the big spending Labor Party. The government has done a great job in reforming the economy. There is high economic growth and the lowest interest rates for 20 years. The government has done a great job and the next great thing to be done is tax reform.

speech.para: The Labor Party are claiming that the government is not doing it correctly. The Labor Party have been trying to drum up support from around the traps to complain to the various Senate committees hearing the implications of tax reform, and virtually every group has come along and said, `We are in favour of tax reform, but not us, please. We have a special case to plead.' Lots of groups have made that plea.

With regard to compensation, all the evidence before the committee is that the government's compensation package is more than adequate. ACOSS's report, using the Melbourne Institute economic modelling, showed clearly that for all the groups they examined, the cost increase was less than the four per cent proposed in the CPI adjustment by the government. The government—on top of the four per cent—has guaranteed a 1½ per cent increase in pensions and entitlements above the CPI. That is what the government has offered, and that is adequate.The weekly earnings adjustment gives two parallel roads for pension adjustment. Whichever wins out, the pensioner wins out with it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to take note of the answers to questions given by Senator Kemp today or, should I say, in respect of the first two questions, a lack of answers given by Senator Kemp to those questions. When you listen to the answers the minister gives to questions, it is obvious that, firstly, he has no comprehension at all of the questions that he is being asked, and, secondly, he gets his answers out of eavesdropping on the Treasurer's telephone calls because he only ever has half the story when he does present something to this chamber. The Treasurer should put his phone calls on speaker so that Senator Kemp can hear the whole story, and maybe we might get some intelligent answers out of Senator Kemp when he is asked a question in this chamber. It is very difficult, but at least, if he heard the whole story, there might be half a chance that we would get an intelligent answer.

speech.para: But he did say in response to a question from Senator Hogg that this government was about keeping its promises. There is one promise it has consistently walked around this country saying that it would keep, and that is that it would compensate people—particularly low income earners—for the effect of the GST. That promise has turned out to be an absolute myth. As Senator Evans said, the myth was exploded by Mr Geoff Carmody, representing the Australian Food and Grocery Council, at hearings on the GST last week. He said that the present compensation package will not endure, and that wage earners would be worse off after just two to three years—not a long-term evaporation of the compensation package but over a two- to three-year period. The Food and Grocery Council is a member of the Business Coalition for Tax Reform—the people who argued for a GST—and it is the first major business group that has directly criticised the adequacy of the compensation package.

What Senator Gibson said is true: we have had innumerable individuals representing a wide range of community groups come before the GST select committee all saying that they want an exemption of one form or another from the impact of the GST. Whether it be those sections that represent the welfare community, the transport industry, the NRMA or other automobile associations, they have all come along with a wish list of exemptions. In fact, if all the exemptions that have been brought before the committee are put into the final report the list will be so substantial it will overwhelm the report. And this is a package that supposedly, this government argues, has substantial support out and about in the community.

Mr Carmody went on to say that the way in which the government had arranged the compensation package—by linking it to inflation rather than tying it to male average weekly earnings—will over time erode the package. Over time it will eventually bring the pensions back to what they were at the point when the compensation package was introduced.

The only person on that side of the chamber who has had the guts to get up and be honest about what the effects of this package will be on low income earners—and I note that you have not put him on the list of people to speak in this debate—was Senator Watson. He had the courage to get up at the Liberal Party meeting in Tasmania last year and call on the government to provide a substantially greater compensation package because the current package was inadequate. And what did you do? As soon as he got to Canberra you put the nobbles on him and he has not been heard arguing that issue since. That is not somebody getting up on this side and arguing the issue; that is one of your own senators, one of the people you parade out. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The issue raised by the Labor Party in question time today is a complete furphy. The witness Carmody before the Senate select committee last week did not say that the government's compensation package is inadequate, nor did he say that the compensation package would be eroded in absolute terms. He simply put forward an argument regarding the relativity between the government's compensation package and our guarantee of pensions being maintained at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. That does not mean in any way, shape or form that the increase being provided to pensions will not be enough to cover the additional costs of living which the GST will cause. That is because the compensation package which the government is offering is more than adequate.

speech.para: Even those economists who provided evidence to the committee and who claim that the price effect of the introduction of a goods and services tax will be more than the 1.9 per cent predicted by Treasury acknowledge that the price effect will still be less than four per cent and the government is guaranteeing a minimum of four per cent compensation to pensioners and other low income earners.

Over and above that the government has guaranteed that, if the CPI effect is higher than estimated, the compensation provided will be 1.5 per cent more than the CPI increase resulting from the goods and services tax. So let there be absolutely no mistake about this: adequate compensation is being provided by the government in its tax reform package.

The issue that Labor is raising today is a red herring. Labor is not concerned about compensation being offered to low income earners in our tax reform package because Labor is not interested in tax reform. The Labor Party has embarked on blanket opposition to the tax reform proposals of the government. Again they are completely ignoring much of the evidence that has been put to the select committee and the other committees examining this evidence. The evidence provided to those committees shows overwhelmingly the need for tax reform, it shows overwhelmingly that our current tax system is broken and beyond repair. The reasons for that are manifold. Firstly, unless tax reform is implemented, people on average weekly earnings today will have a marginal tax rate of 43 per cent. Every extra dollar they earn over average weekly earnings will cost them 43 cents in the dollar tax. Before too long, within the next couple of years, they will be paying 47 cents in the dollar on every extra dollar earned. There is absolutely no incentive in our current income tax structure for people to work either smarter or harder to earn extra dollars because they are going to lose half of it by the year 2000. That punishment to incentive is a major reason why we need urgent tax reform.

Let us also recall that in the early 1950s a person had to be earning something like 17 times average weekly earnings before their marginal tax rate was at the top rate. Yet today, as I said, they will be hitting the top marginal tax rate when they are earning 1.2 or 1.3 times the average weekly earnings. Within the next couple of years people earning average weekly earnings will be hitting the top marginal tax rate. That is just another example of the way in which our current system is broken.

talk.start.para: —Thanks to Labor.

—Thanks to Labor's inexorable tax increases when they were in office, Senator Knowles. Of course, the system is also broken because of our outmoded wholesale sales tax structure. It was introduced in the 1930s when we had an economy based on consumption primarily of goods. Most of what people spent their incomes on was goods—very little was spent on services. Today we have a transformation in consumption spending so that people now spend most of their incomes on services, which do not attract any indirect tax directly. Therefore, we need to change our system to ensure that we have a fair indirect tax that taxes consumption across the board and is not limited to the very narrow base of goods. It is unfair to individuals; it is also unfair to states like South Australia which are still very dependent on the production of goods as part of their economic base—so South Australia bears a disproportionate share of our indirect tax system compared with other states. So in fairness to individuals and to regions of Australia we need to reform our indirect tax system.(Time expired)

—It is important, when taking note of the very insufficient answers from Senator Kemp today, to recognise that the government itself acknowledges that the GST legislation is regressive, and that is why there has to be some compensation. The government knows that this GST legislation requires compensation to even get near to being fair. It advantages the top end of town and it makes it appalling for the people at the lower end of town—that is, the poor people and people on low incomes. There has to be compensation to even begin to make this GST package fair. All of the evidence that we now have is that the compensation is inadequate. It does not work.

speech.para: People came before our committee and said, `This debate is not about economic models, it is about people.' The evidence over and over again from all of the organisations—St Vincent de Paul, Anglicare, the Uniting Church, the councils of social service—looking after poor people, representing them, and providing support and backup for them was that the compensation is not sufficient. It does not work. This is legislation that is writing into law forever a basic unfairness in the Australian society.

The rich will be getting $80 a week in tax cuts and the poor people will be getting $6 a week in compensation. What kind of fairness is that? As one witness in South Australia said, as he held up a packet of Just Right cereal that costs $6.10, people will be getting $6 per week but this one packet of cereal will do away with the compensation for the week. It is clearly not sufficient. That evidence is now confirmed by Professor Carmody. It is unfair because the compensation is a short-term best guess. But the Treasury's models—to return to those terrible things—did not take into account the lowest quintile, that is, the people on the lowest incomes. They were not included.

St Vincent de Paul and others went and interviewed people on very low incomes. They told us, like Treasury cannot, that 30 per cent of the household income of people on low incomes goes on food, and all of that food will be going up by near enough to 10 per cent. Another 30 per cent of their household income goes on housing and that also will increase. The government recognises that in its own document. The compensation clearly will not provide anything like the maintenance of the modest life that people on low incomes have now. It is nothing short of scandalous that this government, which is so clear in what it wants to do, refuses to recognise the evidence.

You would think that the inquiry that has been forced on the government might be used by the government to repair the damage done by its thoughtless and ill-considered—or, as I think, properly considered, because this is the way it wants the world to be: the rich get on and the poor get behind—legislation and that it might take note of some of the evidence. But all the government does is send its ministers—including the insufficient Senator Kemp—in here today to totally disparage the evidence that has been provided by thousands of witnesses, who are not paid stoolies of the Labor Party and who did not come only to say that their organisations would be badly affected, although most of them did say that. But for thousands of organisations it was because they know, from speaking to people on low incomes and from the evidence that they have from the daily lives of families who go in and out of their organisations, how badly these families will be affected. They have done the work and they know how tough it is for people at the moment and they know that the compensation in this legislation will not meet the needs.

It is even worse when you add to that the evidence that it will not last. Within a few years, even by the government's own figuring, the revenue raised by the proposed GST legislation will not do anything more than be back to flat and the government will have to raise the rate of the GST. This is what has happened in every other country, and there is no provision for any adjusted compensation at that level either. Even without going that far down the track, it is clear, despite what the incompetent minister said today, that the compensation package will not go near to providing even maintenance of the current livelihood of people on the low income end of the scale. What kind of legislation gives an $80 tax cut to people on an income above $75,000 and $6 compensation for the poor? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Today we have reached a new peak, I suppose, in the stupidity of this debate from an opposition that is voting against the legislation. We have just heard a dissertation from Senator Crowley, who is complaining that the compensation in this legislation is inadequate. Yet in a Senate Community Affairs hearing, Senator Crowley said that the `CPI adjustment to the pension is effectively a compensation'.
—That is wicked. You have taken that out of context.
—That is exactly what that senator said in the hearings. After the increases by the Labor government—
—That is a lie.

—Senator Crowley interjects as she goes out the door, which is not appropriate for a senator to do, that that is a lie. It is interesting that Senator Crowley uses that type of language, which I have slowly but surely become accustomed to, I might add. But her comment, taken direct from Hansard , is that the CPI adjustment to the pension is effectively a compensation.

speech.para: During the committee hearings, I asked ACOSS whether they had done anything to seek compensation for the 13 years of high taxing by the Labor government. They said that they had consistently sought compensation. Mr Michael Raper, the head of ACOSS, in reference to the Labor government years, said:
The only way that we—
as a country—
have been able to retain the level of revenue from consumption taxes is by hiking up the rates, as was done in 1993—
under a Labor government—
through wholesale sales tax rates being hiked without any compensation. That has contributed to the increased burden on low income earners.
Talking about that burden, Mr Raper also happened to say, on the point that I had made about the impact of indirect taxes on the weekly spending power of low income earners:

It is obvious and clear that that is the case. Indeed it is our research that demonstrates that that impact has increased from 14 per cent of their weekly spending going on indirect taxes to 23 per cent in the last 10 years of their weekly budgets.

That was under the Labor government—without one cent in compensation. Yet Senator Crowley said, `The CPI's enough to cover you,' for an increase of up to 23 per cent of impact. The tax package is offering a four per cent increase, up-front, paid in advance, plus a 1½ per cent increase above the CPI. The Labor opposition have consistently argued, as this Hansard proves, that they believed the CPI increase was adequate. Yet their own figures and the figures of people who traditionally supported them say that their tax increases had that sort of effect.

We need to be reminded also of what Labor promised pensioners at the last election: nothing. They promised absolutely nothing other than a retrospective tax on their pre-1985 assets. That was what Labor offered pensioners at the last election: a retrospective capital gains tax on their pre-1985 assets.

talk.start.para: —No, we didn't. Tell the truth.

—Tell the truth? That was the Labor Party policy and that was exactly the policy that was released prior to the election. Labor promised not a dollar of benefit to pensioners. If senators opposite want to get up and contradict that, you point out in your policy documents where you promised any benefits to pensioners.

speech.para: It was the coalition that promised the 25 per cent benchmark for pensioners, not the Labor Party. Not one cent was given when you were in office. I do not know why you are really worried about it. Senator Chris Evans sums it up all the time. Senator Chris Evans has already said on two occasions, if not more—there are only two that I can find today in this short time—`I am a Labor Party senator and we are voting against it.' He said, just as a bit of advice to witnesses, `I just oppose a GST on everything.' (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the Australian Government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian Government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That Australian citizens oppose social, legal and economic discrimination against people on the basis of their sexuality or transgender identity and that such discrimination is unacceptable in a democratic society.

Your petitioners request that the Senate should: pass the Australian Democrats Bill to make it unlawful to discriminate or vilify on the basis of sexuality or transgender identity so that such discrimination or vilification be open to redress at a national level.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett(from 165 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in the Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned draws attention to the potentially damaging effects of National Competition Policy on small business such as newsagents.

Your petitioners ask the Senate in Parliament to call on the federal government to review the decisions of the Australian Consumer and Competition Tribunal which threaten the viability of newsagents and introduce legislation to override these decisions and preserve the current system of distribution for magazines and newspapers through Australian newsagents.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett(from 46 citizens)

That services and goods provided by natural and traditional therapy practitioners are an integral component of Australia's health care system and should be included in the health care exempt (zero rated) category under the Government's proposed Tax Reform Package. Preclusion implies a discrimination and could seriously restrict the choice of affordable health care available to Australians.

Your Petitioners request that services and goods provided by natural and traditional therapy practitioners be included in the health care exempt (zero rated) category under the Government's proposed Tax Reform Package.

talk.start.para: The President(from 19 citizens)
Senator Lees(from 724 citizens)

petition.para: The petition of the undersigned draws attention to the Senate the regressive nature of the Enrolment Benchmark Adjustment (EBA) which increases funding for private school places by taking money out of the public education.
Your petitioners call on the Australian Government to:
(1) Immediately abolish the EBA.
(2) Introduce a fair funding system for public education.

talk.start.para: Senator Allison(from 22 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows: that Australian students oppose any form of VSU on the basis that it is not in the best interests of all students, for the reasons given below:

that Voluntary Student Unionism reduces students' representation by weakening student associations and limiting their power to work for students' best interests alongside (and occasionally in conflict with) tertiary institutions and governments;

that VSU leads to students benefiting from services which only a section of the student community has paid for and that student unionism should be considered in the same category as taxation, a necessary subsidy for public services;

that VSU leads to declines in student facilities and campus infrastructure, disadvantaging not just current but future students, who will suffer from the lower levels of representation and services even more than current students.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Ian Campbell to move, on the next day of sitting:
That—

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the following bills, allowing them to be considered during this period of sittings:
Airports Amendment Bill 1999
Assistance for Carers Legislation Amendment Bill 1999
Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1999
Financial Management Legislation Amendment Bill 1999
Referendum Legislation Amendment Bill 1999.
I table statements of reasons justifying the need for these bills to be considered during these sittings and seek leave to have the statements incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statements read as follows—

The Bill proposes several amendments to the Airports Act 1996 (the Act) directed at implementing Government policy for the competitive provision of services at leased federal airports and facilitating more effective administration of the Act and federal Airport Leases.
The proposed amendments encompass:

- an extension of time available to airport lessees to have access undertakings to certain airport services approved by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC). The currant provisions under section 192 of the Act require approval of access undertakings within 12 months of lease. The proposed changes will give Phase 2 airport lessees sufficient time to settle all relevant matters through consultation with the ACCC. The experience of Phase 1 operators was that there was insufficient time to do so, due to other regulatory burdens (such as preparation of Master Plans and Environment Strategies) in the first year of the Airport Lease. The result was that Phase 1 lessees were unable to have access undertakings approved by the ACCC in the time permitted by the Act. It is hoped to avoid this problem in Phase 2;
- amendments to overcome some practical difficulties associated with day-to-day administration of Airport Leases; and
- an amendment to protect controlled airspace.

The first of the Phase 2 airports was leased on 28 May 1998. If the Bill is not passed by 28 May 1999 (12 months later), then the opportunity to easily extend the period for approval of access undertakings for Phase 2 airports under section 192 of the Act will pass.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services)

para.inline: ASSISTANCE FOR CARERS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1999

speech.para: The Assistance for Carers Bill 1999 deals with a number of measures aimed at improving assistance to carers. These were announced as part of the 1997 and 1998 Budgets.

The measures are now due for implementation on 1 July 1999. There will need to be significant, and complex, changes to the computer systems in order to implement the measures. To ensure that these changes are in place, and to help minimise the risks associated with changes of this nature, it will be important to offer as stable a micropolicy environment as is possible during the system design and development phases. Passage of the legislation in the 1999 Autumn Sittings would provide a solid basis from which to progress the implementation, and therefore avoid undue problems in delivering financial assistance to carers.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Family and Community Services)

To amend the Bounty (Ships) Act 1989 so as to extend the shipbuilding bounty from 1 July 1999 at a rate of 3% until 31 December 2000, and introduce the Shipbuilding Innovation Scheme (SIS). The purpose of the SIS is to encourage a strengthened focus on product and process research and development and design innovation in the shipbuilding industry. The SIS will provide payment of a benefit calculated at 50% of investment in eligible research and development up to an amount equal to 2% of eligible production costs. This is a five year program costing $40 million in the first four years
The current bounty ceases on 30 June 1999 and the amendment Bill needs to be introduced to continue bounty payments from 1 July 1999. Payments under the SIS will commence on 1 July 1999.

Failure to pass the Bill in the Autumn sittings could lead to a gap between the cessation of the current bounty scheme (June 1999) and the commencement of the new bounty scheme which will disadvantage the shipbuilding industry in the international market place.

Any delay in passing the Bill could have a negative impact on the shipbuilding industry and subject the industry to a double adjustment. Any gap between cessation of the current scheme and introduction of the new scheme will expose the industry to a comparative price disadvantage compared to European competitors. This could result in loss of market share that may not be recoverable.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Industy, Science and Resources)

The Government has decided to implement an accrual based financial framework to replace the existing cash based framework. This will mean the Government will budget, manage and report on an accrual basis from the year 1999-2000. From the May 1999 budget, the appropriation bills will be recast to reflect the new framework.

The Financial Management Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 will facilitate the move to the new financial framework by simplifying the legislative and administrative requirements for fund accounting. In essence, the Bill will collapse the present four funds into one Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) and replace the requirement for the Minister for Finance to prepare a monthly financial statement of fund transactions with monthly financial statements prepared on an accrual basis.

New accrual based systems being introduced by agencies are not designed to perform fund accounting and may need to be modified to do so. This process could be expensive for some agencies, reduce the efficiency of their systems, and would serve no useful purpose apart from ensuring compliance with legislation. Fund accounting information is not required for financial management or reporting and is not used for decision making.

If passage of the bill were delayed, there may not be sufficient time for agencies to implement necessary system requirements by 1 July and for development of appropriation bills in a new format for a May Budget.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Finance and Administration)

To amend the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 to allow for expenditure by the Government on public information activities leading up to the referendum on a republic foreshadowed for 1999. The significant nature of this referendum makes amendment of the Act necessary, to ensure that the public is well informed on all relevant issues before being required to vote on the matter.

Reasons for urgency requiring introduction and passage in the same sittings Current provisions of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 constrain government expenditure on referendum-related public information activities. The provisions could severely limit the public information programme and assistance for the public presentation of the cases for and against change. Passage of the Bill before the introduction of the Constitutional Alteration (Republic) Bills in the 1999 Winter Sittings is essential to ensure that appropriate public information activities may be carried out to meet the interest created by the introduction of those Bills, and that preparation of the `yes' and `no' campaigns may commence.

para.inline: Effect if the Bill is not dealt with in one sittings

speech.para: It would affect the timing of the commencement of the public information programme, constrain the preparation of the `yes' and `no' campaigns, and could delay the referendum timetable.

The Hon Alexander Downer MP

Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Instrument of Approval of Forms made under subsection 30(2) of the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994 , which grants approval to forms 1RA, 1RP, 2RA, 2RP, 3RA and 3RP.

Although the Instrument was made on 12 October 1998, it is stated to have had effect from 4 September 1998. There is no indication that this retrospectivity does not prejudicially affect the rights of a person other than the Commonwealth and may therefore be of no effect.
The Committee notes that although the Forms themselves are numbered, the Instrument is not provided with any unique identifying number or symbol.

Forms 2RA and 2RP indicate that the signature at the foot of the form is (inter alia) a declaration that the information provided is `true and correct in every material particular', but the other Forms do not include such a statement. There is no indication that the information to be provided by the other forms does not need to be accurate. Also, the forms, especially 2RA and 2RP, do not contain a statement of the consequences of either refusing to provide the information, or of providing information which is not true and correct in every material particular.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
19 December 1998
Dear Bill

I refer to your letter of 2 December 1998 regarding the Instrument of Approval of Forms made under subsection 30(2) of the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994 (the Act), which grants approval to forms 1RA, 1RP, 2RA, 2RP, 3RA and 3RP.

I note the Committee's comments on retrospectivity and would like to assure the Committee that retrospective application of this Instrument has not adversely affected the rights of any person. The need for retrospective application of the instrument arose from complications in timing with respect to entry into force of those provisions in the Act enabling the Instruments to be made (7 October), and the need to collect the information necessary to prepare Australia's annual declarations to the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, required under the Chemical Weapons Convention, by 31 October.

I note that the Explanatory Memorandum prepared for the Instrument should have included words making clear that its retrospective application was not prejudicial to the rights of any person (other than the Commonwealth), and that its omission was an oversight.

As is current practice, the Instrument is referenced by date and signature rather than any unique identifying number or symbol. If, however, the Committee considers such a numbering system appropriate, then I will ensure that such arrangements are implemented in the future.

The forms approved by the Instrument of 12 October 1998 apply to existing permit holders under the Act. Information provided previously to those persons has noted the existence of penalties for provision of false or misleading information in any document given pursuant to the Act. Nevertheless, the Committee has made a valid point about the need for these provisions to be highlighted on documents such as approved forms, and the forms will be amended to this effect before the next set of reporting obligations falls due.
Yours sincerely
Alexander Downer
