talk.start.para: —Firstly, I want to express my great sympathy for Senator Colston, who is very ill and I am sure has the sympathy of everybody in this chamber. But we are in a unique situation in the Senate where Senator Colston's particular absence is pivotal to the outcome of a number of votes which are coming down the line to do with matters of immense national importance. I only have to flag the GST legislation, legislation to do with the republic, legislation to do with the comprehensive overhaul of environmental laws in this country and a matter before the Senate just today, the potential sale of a further tranche of Telstra shares.

speech.para: I think that under those circumstances the mover of the motion would be very helpful to the Senate were he able to enlighten us a little more as to the illness of Senator Colston. We obviously have no right or prerogative to be trespassing on matters of intense personal importance, but it would be helpful if the Senate were able to hear—I for one would hope to hear this—that Senator Colston is likely to be back here representing his electorate and able to vote at the expiry of the time proposed to be granted.

I particularly think it would be helpful to the Senate, and indeed the nation, to know whether Senator Colston has got the fortune to have medical advice that he will be able to attend the Senate before the end of June, because in that time all of these matters are going to be dealt with. As I said, Senator Colston's vote could be pivotal to whether legislation of such importance passes the Senate or otherwise.

I did not rise on this matter lightly. I am particularly sympathetic, as I said, to Senator Colston's position, but I am also aware of the responsibility we have to see that the democratic process is carried out in the full. In this peculiar situation which has never arisen before in the Senate, if Senator Colston is returning then we can rest easy with that but, if he is not, some arrangement can be made to at least have an indication of how he would vote, so that we might move—for example, through the good offices of the Senate—to take into account that vote when considering these matters of enormous importance to the nation. We have an ethical situation here which is unprecedented, but I believe it is very important that the matter be raised, that members of the Senate give it a great deal of thought and that we even prevail upon Senator Colston or those who are advising him—and that includes his medical advisers—to enlighten the Senate as to how the future stands regarding not only his health but also these extraordinarily important matters which are coming before the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
