Secondly, I point out that Australia is the one that signed the convention. Australia agreed with the convention as long ago as 1966. If we no longer agree with it, perhaps we had better say so. We cannot have it both ways. Either we agree with it and we uphold it, or we are going to have to accept that we will be criticised for breaching it. Point 6 of the committee's decision states:

The Committee, having considered a series of new amendments to the Native Title Act, as adopted in 1998, expresses concern over the compatibility of the Native Title Act, as currently amended, with the State Party's international obligations underneath the Convention. While the original Native Title Act recognizes and seeks to protect indigenous title, provisions that extinguish or impair the exercise of indigenous title rights and interests pervade the amended Act. While the original 1993 Native Title Act was delicately balanced between the rights of indigenous and non-indigenous title holders, the amended Act appears to create legal certainty for governments and third parties at the expense of indigenous title.

This is in direct contravention of the intentions of the convention. The committee notes, in particular, four specific provisions that discriminate against indigenous title holders. These include: validation provisions; confirmation of extinguishment provisions; the primary production upgrade provisions; and restrictions concerning the right of indigenous title holders to negotiate non-indigenous land uses.

These provisions raise concerns that the amended act appears to wind back the protections of indigenous title offered in the Mabo decision in the High Court of Australia and the original 1993 Native Title Act. Point 9 states:

The lack of effective participation by indigenous communities in the formulation of the amendments also raises concerns with respect to the State Party's compliance with its obligations under Article 5(c) of the Convention. Calling upon States Parties to `recognise and protect the rights of indigenous peoples to own, develop, control and use their common lands, territories and resources,' the Committee, in its General Recommendation XXIII, stressed the importance of ensuring `that members of indigenous peoples have equal rights in respect of effective participation in public life, and that no decisions directly relating to their rights and interests are taken without their informed consent.'
Point 10 states:

While welcoming the State Party's recognition of the important role that has been played by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the Committee also notes with concern the State Party's proposed changes to the overall structure of the Commission; abolishing the position of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner and assigning those functions to a generalist Deputy President.

There seems to be great confusion about this issue. In this place only two weeks ago I congratulated the Attorney-General on reinstating this position, notwithstanding the fact that legislation abolishing the position has already passed the House of Representatives and is in this place to be debated. Nevertheless, the Attorney-General put out a press release naming Dr Bill Jonas as the new Social Justice Commissioner—or so I thought. Apparently that is not the intention. I really would like that to be cleared up because I am certainly confused. I would not have dreamt of congratulating the Attorney-General if that was not his intent. It certainly was the impression he gave but apparently that is not to be. No doubt we will have a full debate about those matters when that amended bill comes before us in this chamber.

The committee has called on Australia to address these concerns as a matter of utmost urgency. Most importantly, in conformity with the committee's general recommendation No. XXIII concerning indigenous peoples, the committee urges the State Party to suspend implementation of the 1998 amendments and to reopen discussions with representatives of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples with a view to finding solutions acceptable to the indigenous peoples and which would comply with Australia's obligations under the convention. Finally, point 12 states:

In light of the urgency and fundamental importance of these matters, and taking into account the willingness expressed by the State Party to continue dialogue with the Committee over these provisions, the Committee decides to keep this matter on its agenda under its early warning and urgent action procedures to be reviewed again at its fifty-fifth session.
I understand that is in August.

This is a matter of grave concern for all Australians. It is our international reputation that is at stake here. I understand what it is like whenever we are criticised. When I am criticised I like to try to make the best of a bad situation and make excuses. That is only natural. We have had the Attorney-General making excuses and saying that the report is ill informed and insulting, and he has dismissed it. I understand that reaction; we do not like being told that we are wrong. But he is going to have to reconsider it.

Also, I heard that the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation, the Hon. Philip Ruddock, made a similar statement. He was quite dismissive, saying that this report means absolutely nothing. It will mean something when it is in the General Assembly in October or November. How will Australia feel when this report is given to all nations in the General Assembly in New York? It is all very well to bluff through and say that Australia does not care and that it really does not matter. Of course Australia cares. Of course we are going to have to find some mechanism to address these concerns and do it in a way that is acceptable to the government. I accept that the government is extremely sensitive about it.

The obvious way to deal with this criticism is for the amended legislation to be immediately referred to the joint parliamentary committee monitoring native title. Having served on that committee for nearly six years, I believe that is our role. At the very least the government should refer the bill immediately for a report and it should immediately set up direct consultations with the National Indigenous Working Group and with other concerned indigenous leaders. Obviously ATSIC would be one of them.

This is, as reported in Unity News, which publishes the diary dates for United Nations observances, the week of solidarity for peoples struggling against racism and racial discrimination. Already there is an occasion at Westminster in London tonight Australian time when, at the House of Commons at 4 o'clock, there will be a meeting of members of parliament, trade unions, non-government organisation representatives and other influential speakers who will stand in solidarity with Aboriginal people as they call on the British government to show concern about this matter. There will also be a candlelight vigil outside Australia House. Is this the kind of action that we want to see? First the United Nations and now London. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Millen, Colonel Brian: Visit to East Timor
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 378)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 December 1998:

question.para: With reference to the recent visit East Timor by Defence Attache Colonel Brian Millen.

(1) Was the focus of the Defence Attache's visit to East Timor to investigate claims of a further massacre of up to 100 East Timorese by Indonesian troops following the massacre at Santa Cruz cemetery.
(2) Was the focus of the Defence Attache's visit to monitor Indonesian troop movements and numbers.
(3) What were the findings of the Defence Attache in respect of paragraphs (1) and (2).
(4) Did the Defence Attache meet with Indonesian military officers and members of the local East Timorese population during the visit.
(5) What were Colonel Millen's findings and recommendation to the Government.
(6) Will the report be made public.

(7) In the interest of transparency, and to enable independent observers such as the International Red Cross and Amnesty International to monitor the situation in East Timor, does the Minister not agree that this can only be achieved by publicly releasing the Defence Attache's report.
(8) Does the Minister not agree that the only way to effectively stop human rights violations is to publicly expose those abuses, and those who perpetrate them.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Colonel Millen, then Australia's Army Attache to Indonesia, visited East Timor over the period 2 to 6 December 1998. The purpose and nature of the visit changed between the time it had been planned and the time it took place, as a result of the allegations of a massacre at Alas and concerns expressed by the Government about those allegations. As a consequence, Alas was added to the itinerary of the visit, both to enable a better assessment of claims regarding what had happened and also to demonstrate to the Indonesian authorities that we were deeply concerned about the reports of a massacre. Colonel Millen was also tasked to inquire about troop numbers in East Timor. As with most regional visits undertaken by Australian Embassy staff, including Defence staff, the Army Attache's visit involved a number of other objectives. In this case, among other things, it included introducing the in-coming Army Attache to relevant interlocutors in East Timor.

(3) and (5) In accordance with normal procedure Colonel Millen completed a report of his visit. I do not intend to discuss all the details of that report, however Colonel Millen did comment on the alleged massacre in Alas and the question of troop numbers. Colonel Millen reported that the incident in Alas appeared to be more of a civil disturbance involving a number of parties rather than a military attack. His observations did not substantiate claims that a massacre had occurred although he could confirm that houses had been burned and between 1 and 9 people had been killed in fighting. The military commander in East Timor informed Colonel Millen that there were 12,000 troops in East Timor at that time, although the visit did not provide Colonel Millen the opportunity to substantiate that number.

(4) The visit was carried out in full consultation with the Indonesian authorities. Colonel Millen met with the military commander of East Timor, a number of other military officers, and members of the East Timorese community, including the Governor and Deputy Governor of the province, during the course of his visit.

(6) and (7) The report is a highly classified document that contains information provided to Colonel Millen in confidence by Indonesian officials. As such it will not be released to the public. It would not have any particular value for independent observers such as the Red Cross or Amnesty International. Furthermore, the public release of this report would undermine the strong relationship we have with Indonesia.

(8) The most effective way to curb human rights violations in Indonesia is for the Indonesian Government to improve professional military standards and accountability throughout the armed forces. The Indonesian Government is taking steps to improve human rights in their country. The Australian Government has encouraged the Indonesian Armed Forces (ABRI) to use restraint when dealing with civil unrest, and has expressed its concerns regarding human rights abuses to the Indonesian Government and ABRI on many occasions. We continue to encourage the Indonesian Government to take action against those found responsible for human rights abuses.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 9 February 1999:

question.para: (1) What is the Government's official position on self-determination both in domestic and international policy.

(2) (a) What was the rationale for moving to `self-management' and `self-empowerment'; (b) on what basis was this change made; (c) where did the impetus come from; (d) which agency was responsible for the preparation of the Cabinet submissions; and (e) which other government departments provided advice on the matter.
(3) What consultation processes were undertaken with indigenous peoples, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) and other relevant groups in relation to this change.

(4) Given that ATSIC has been described by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs as the leading national advisory body on indigenous affairs, why was ATSIC not included in the processes leading up to the Cabinet decision.

(5) Has the Government and/or the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade sought to influence other governments to downgrade the language of self-determination in the draft declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples; if not, will they try to do so.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government's position on self-determination in the context of the UN negotiations on a Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples is that it is unable to accept the term "self-determination" as it is used in the Draft Declaration because "self-determination" has no settled meaning and for many it implies establishment of separate nations or separate laws. The Government does not question the legitimate aspirations of indigenous peoples to enjoy meaningful participation in decision-making and political processes and greater autonomy over their affairs, but there is a difference between this and the way "self-determination" could be interpreted in the Draft Declaration. Australia is seeking more appropriate and alternative language to "self-determination" in the referring articles. This position was conveyed by the Australian delegation to the meeting of the UN Working Group on the Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples in Geneva on 7 December 1998.

(2) At the 7 December 1998 meeting of the UN Working Group, the Australian delegation conveyed the Government's view that it would be more productive for the Working Group to look at alternative language to "self-determination" in the Draft Declaration which would more accurately express the principle of indigenous peoples having greater opportunities to exercise meaningful control over their affairs. The Government believes this to be a more positive approach than the alternative proposal of introducing clarifications or qualifications to references to "self-determination" in the text of the document. The remaining aspects of this question relate to Ministerial and Cabinet advice.
(3) The Government regularly consults States and Territories and interest groups, including the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, on issues relating to the Draft Declaration.

(4) Because ATSIC has chosen to participate in United Nations forums as a `non-government organisation', it is precluded from internal Govern ment policy deliberations concerning issues to be discussed at those forums.

(5) Over the years many countries in the Working Group have expressed their concerns about the ambiguity of the term "self-determination" in the Draft Declaration. At the December 1998 Geneva meeting, most delegations which spoke on this issue expressed concern that the term "self-determination" was ambiguous and ill-defined and required further discussion. The Australian delegation discussed its approach to the Draft Declaration, including the use of the term "self-determination", with other delegations involved in the Working Group, including the delegations of Canada, New Zealand and the USA.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Science and Resources: Sinclair Knight Scoping Study
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 402)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 12 February 1999:

question.para: (1) Did a company, Sinclair Knight, undertake a scoping study of the Western Tasmania region; if so, what was the cost of the work.
(2) (a) What was the outcome of that work: and (b) can a copy be provided of the resulting report.
(3) Has any further work been undertaken since that work was completed.

(4) Given that, at an estimates hearing in 1998, the department advised that a full study of the region would cost in the order of $180,000: (a) is that still the department's estimate for the work: (b) is that full study to proceed: and (c) who will meet the cost of the study.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The cost, which is "commercial in confidence", was met by the Tasmanian Department of Mineral Resources (TDMR).

(2) (a) The outcome was a report by Sinclair Knight Merz Pty. Ltd. which formed the basis for the Terms of Reference used in the Request for Proposal, issued by TDMR on 27 August 1998, for consultants to undertake the Western Tasmanian Regional Minerals Study. (b) a copy of the Terms of Reference will be forwarded to Senator O'Brien.
(3) Yes, see below.

(4) (a) The final bid accepted for the study was within the estimate of $180,000 provided in 1998. (b) Yes, two finalists were interviewed by the Management Committee (which comprises industry, the Commonwealth and State Government) in Burnie on 20 November 1998. AGC Woodward Clyde Pty Limited was selected as the preferred tenderer and work commenced in January 1999. The study will produce a Developers Guide to Western Tasmania and determine priorities for infrastructure development. It is due for completion in September 1999. (c) The cost of the study is to be met jointly by the Department of Industry, Science and Resources through the Regional Minerals Program, TDMR and the industry through the Tasmanian Minerals Council.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 15 February 1999:

question.para: What is Centrelink's practice in relation to the retention of individual client records, in particular (a) what records of individuals are kept; (b) in what form are such records kept; (c) what are the conditions, if any, applying to recalling those retained records; and (d) is there a time limit on the retention and use of these records.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The retention of individual client records by Centrelink is subject to Record Disposal Authorities (RDAs) issued by the National Archives of Australia under the Archives Act 1983 and the agreements between Centrelink and the various client departments on behalf of which Centrelink provides services.
Without the details of the individual client circumstances only general answers can be provided to the remaining questions with the exception of part (b):
(a) only sufficient information is requested and retained to access and record an entitlement under the appropriate benefit legislation for a payment and details to enable payment to be made;

(b) records have to be retained in paper and electronic form. Paper records are retained for evidential reasons because in some States and the Northern Territory electronic evidence is not yet admissible in Court. Electronic records are retained for operational and statistical purposes;
(c) only Centrelink officers in the course of their duties are allowed to recall retained records;

(d) under the authority of the Archives Act, retention periods range from permanently (forever) to destruction after one year of inactivity. If an individual client record exists a customer service officer will use this information to assist in delivering a high level of service and to ensure the best possible outcome for the client.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 25 February 1999:

question.para: (1) What variations exist between Australian maximum residue limits (MRLs) for pesticides in Australian primary industry commodities and MRLs for those commodities set in: (a) Japan; (b) the United States of America; (c) New Zealand; (d) Korea; (e) the United Kingdom; (f) Hong Kong; (g) Singapore; (h) Taiwan; (i) China; (j) Indonesia; and (k) the European Union.

(2) Are all countries in (1) obliged to comply with: (a) the Agreement on Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures (SPS); and (b) the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT), in the setting of MRLs for pesticides for primary industry commodities.

(3) Are any of the countries in (1) in breach of their obligations under both the SPS and the TBT agreements in relation to the MRLs they apply to imported primary industry commodities from Australia.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Maximum residue limits of agricultural and veterinary chemicals are based on their safe use under conditions necessary for effective and reliable control of pests and diseases. The conditions that determine this safe use include pest pressure, climate, soil types, agricultural practices, crop types and other factors. These vary from country to country, and as a consequence, so can individual MRLs.
All countries regularly make additions to, and deletions from, their lists of MRLs. Likewise, countries alter individual MRLs from time to time as conditions of use change.

Australia has about 4,000 maximum residue limits established for residues of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in food commodities. The number of MRLs established by each of the countries listed are of the same magnitude. It is therefore not possible, in a practical sense, to state what variations exist between MRLs in the countries named above.

To the extent possible, national bodies responsible for the establishment of MRLs in their countries try to harmonise the limits internationally, but this is only possible in a limited number of cases.

(2) All countries which have acceded to the WTO must comply with all WTO agreements in Annex 1A, which includes the Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures and the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade.

Regulations which set allowable levels of pesticide or veterinary drug residues fall under the Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures. In this instance, therefore, the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade is not relevant.
All the customs territories listed above, except China and Taiwan, are members of the WTO. Both of these are negotiating accession to the WTO, and are currently observers.
(3) I am not aware of any WTO cases which have demonstrated a breach of obligations concerning MRLs, or of any current concerns under the Agreement on Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 2 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Has the department, its predecessor, or any of its agencies, undertaken an economic assessment of the Australian horse racing industry; if so: (a) when was that research undertaken; and (b) who undertook the work.
(2) What is the value of the contribution the horse racing industry makes to the Australian economy.
(3) How many people are employed directly and indirectly by the horse racing industry.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Bureau of Agriculture & Resource Economics (ABARE), the economic research section of the department of Agriculture Fisheries and Forestry has done no research on this issue.
(2) ABARE does not collect data on the horse racing industry.
(3) See answer to question 2.
